Description: Digital photograph (colour); view of engraved rock art on a boulder, showing the pecked outlines of a bull and an unidentified quadruped animal. Both animals are upright and facing left, the topmost one is of indeterminate species (mythical?) with a roughly pecked infill and long spindly legs facing left with long neck - gazelle with exaggerated features? gerenuk? Peckmarks around tail are unclear - mythical? It is rendered as if standing directly on the back of the bull, which faces left with clearly delineated u shaped horns, tail, legs and sheath. Its muzzle and front feet are cut off the edge of the image on the right. To the left of these figures is part of an unidentified, pecked, infilled figure, cut off the edge of the image. A 5cm photo scale has been fitted at the base of the image. Wadi Hamra, Egypt. Scanned
Curator's comments: Wadi Hamra is a canyon-like valley with a relatively flat floor between one and 200m wide, curling more or less south into the Gilf Kebir plateau in Egypt’s Western Desert. There are three known rock art sites, all for engravings and first reported by Has Rhotert in 1952: The first is an old river terrace with numerous engravings of giraffe and a few of ostrich, cattle and abstract fan-shaped grooves, with stone circles and shallow depressions on the top. The second is several engravings further southwest. The third stands opposite the branch containing the first site: a rocky outcrop about 15 m high with a number of engravings along the base.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Trust for African Rock Art
